thread.title: What holidays are really like in China
thread.title_full: What holidays are really like in China

title: What holidays are really like in China
text:
Email a friend 
IMAGINE dealing with these crowds on your yearly summer holiday? 
Most of us love a good whinge about public transport, traffic and generally waiting longer than ten minutes in a queue at the bank. 
As these images taken in China show, the population of approximately 1.4 billion have to endure a lot more in the waiting department than we do. To compare, Australia’s population is approximately 23 million. 
“China’s population is expected to peak at 1.41 billion in 2025 and the total population in 2050 will be much lower than it is today,” said Zhang Juewei , deputy director general at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. 
Enjoy the hour long queue at your local theme park this summer season, and just remember, it’s not so bad. Bet your commute home isn’t as hectic as this. Vehicles are seen stuck in a traffic jam near a toll station as people return home at the end of a week-long national day holiday, in Beijing, China, October 6, 2015. Picture taken October 6, 2015. Picture: China Daily Source: Reuters This whole scene looks stressful. Tourists crowd onto Fujiazhuang beach to cool themselves as the temperature reaches 30 degrees, on August 16, 2015 in Dalian, China. Picture: ChinaFotoPress Source: Getty Images This is a line for a job fair, not an actual job. Junior college students line up outside a job fair in Zhengzhou, Henan province, February 15, 2014. According to local media, around 50,000 people attended the job fair on Saturday morning. Picture: Reuters Source: Picture Media 
CHINA’S MASSIVE POPULATION Last Train Home 86:37 
Every spring, 130 million migrant workers journey from China's cities to their home villages for the New Year holiday. March 23rd 2015
